subject: Re: Rule annotation

messageBody:
I guess it would be a way of confirming the test ran before tearing down, since even a failed assumption in the first line of the test will still have the @After method run, in case what you initiated never happened, so there is nothing to tear down. It isn't that important in practice though.

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, David Saff <david@...> wrote:
>
> The way I saw it, a failed assumption prevents a test from running,
> and in an @After method, it's too late to prevent the test from
> running, so it wasn't possible to give assume*() its standard meaning.
> What meaning are you proposing?
>
> David Saff
>
> On Thu, Aug 20, 2009 at 11:29 AM, yme0987654321<yme0987654321@...> wrote:
> > That should be doable. I'll confirm. Probably better than the @Before given that I need inheritance anyway.
> >
> > In the mean time, I had put an assumeThat on the @Before method, and that worked fine (subclasses call super and redeclare the annotation, so all is well). However, for the @After method, the assumeThat method just makes the test fail. I guess it was somewhat surprising that the teardown is run even if the setup fails an assumeThat assumption, but I can certainly understand that. But why not tollerate an assumeThat in teardown? I agree it is somewhat strange that you already ran the test and still want to assume it away, but I would still think that assume should stop a test at all three levels (@Before, the test and @After). What do you think?
> >
> > --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, David Saff <david@> wrote:
> >>
> >> That's right: Rules can affect the processing after @Before and before
> >> @After.  Could you replace your setup/teardown with an
> >> ExternalResource rule?
> >>
> >>    David Saff
> >>
> >> On Thu, Aug 20, 2009 at 11:11 AM, yme0987654321<yme0987654321@> wrote:
> >> > OK, I figured out the problem. What happens is that I have a custom runner that suppresses the test (these are slow tests, so they are only run at check-in, not by the developer while developing).
> >> >
> >> > However, when I replace that with a Rule, the setup method is still run (looks slow). So I guess the conclusion is that @Rule can't interrupt or override the setup and teardown process, so if you need to do that you are back to a Runner? (Or making your own setups rule-aware I guess).
> >> >
> >> > --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, David Saff <david@> wrote:
> >> >>
> >> >> Yishai,
> >> >>
> >> >> I just ran a test, and the Rules in the superclass were picked up.
> >> >> Can you post a small example?  Thanks,
> >> >>
> >> >>    David Saff
> >> >>
> >> >> On Thu, Aug 20, 2009 at 10:21 AM, David Saff<david@> wrote:
> >> >> > Yishai,
> >> >> >
> >> >> > Sounds like a bug.  Can you file it at github?  Sorry for the oversight,
> >> >> >
> >> >> >   David Saff
> >> >> >
> >> >> > On Wed, Aug 19, 2009 at 8:26 PM, yme0987654321<yme0987654321@> wrote:
> >> >> >> I'm looking at the new Rule annotation in JUnit4. It's pretty nice, but it doesn't seem to inherit.
> >> >> >>
> >> >> >> That is if I have a super class that has the @Rule, sub class tests don't run the rule on its tests.
> >> >> >>
> >> >> >> Combined with the requirement that the rules field be public, this is surprising.
> >> >> >>
> >> >> >> The practical effect for me is that it can't really replace my custom runner, as the @RunWith annotation is inherited by subclasses.
> >> >> >>
> >> >> >> Am I missing something?
> >> >> >>
> >> >> >> Yishai.
